texts.definition: Game worlds that become smaller as gameplay progresses.
markups: <style="Definition">Game worlds that become smaller as gameplay progresses.</style>

Some games, primarily those where player compete against each other, decrease the size of the game world as game play progresses. These <style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game Worlds</style> make sure that player will eventually encounter each other.

Most of the stones placed while playing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> are not removed, leading to players having an effectively <style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game World</style>. The same is true in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hey!%20That's%20My%20Fish!">Hey! That's My Fish!</link></style>, but in this case it is due to players removing ice tiles each time it is their turn. Building harvesters are required in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Greed%20Corp">Greed Corp</link></style> to get new resources but each time these are activated they remove a layer of the tile they are on and those surrounding it which eventually leads to the tiles disappearing.

The gameplay area shrinks in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bomberman%20series">Bomberman series</link></style> if players fail to eliminate each other within a certain period of time. One of the multiplayer levels in [Half-Life]], ''Crossfire'' allows players to activate air strikes. Players not in a bunker when these arrive are killed, in effect reducing the gameplay area to the bunker for periods of the matches.

<style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game Worlds</style> have two prime characteristics: in what way <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> shrink and in what way the shrinkage is activated. It is however important that each shrinkage is an <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Event</link></style> since otherwise the game effect instead becomes that of a <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game World</link></style> (one could theoretically conceive of games where sometimes reductions are countered by  growths in other areas but overall <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> become smaller with time). Having <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> even if the "destruction" can simply be its removal, it one way of creating <style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game Worlds</style> and can do this with clear units for the shrinkage (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Greed%20Corp">Greed Corp</link></style>).

The reduction of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> size can simply be a matter of <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> (as in multiplayer games in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bomberman%20series">Bomberman series</link></style>) or be required action by players during their turn in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game Worlds</style> are <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> that instantiate <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Show%20Must%20Go%20On">The Show Must Go On</link></style> but successively making <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> smaller as gameplay takes place. They increase <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> by creating <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> which in turn can limit players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>. That <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> shrink can be seen as an <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effect</link></style> in these worlds, and these can effectively become <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> for players - especially if other players can affect which parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> are removed (as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hey!%20That's%20My%20Fish!">Hey! That's My Fish!</link></style>). By definition, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that are to shrink need to be <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> and the actual shrinkage is a reconfiguration. If players can control the shrinkage this allows <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player Defined Goals</link></style> and a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Constructed%20Worlds">Player Constructed Worlds</link></style>.

As the actual shrinking are <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Shrinking Game Worlds</style> can both guarantee <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> since players are force to share a more limited space and outcomes of struggles become more and more vital for the final outcome of the game instances.
